description:
Once upon a time… not a literature quiz! Focus on the stories! We ask you to write your own bestseller!

Just like in an unforgettable novel, there are big laughs or even deep conversations waiting for you in this game. Once upon a time, there was no one - there was once a character you bring to life…, a dramatic turn that no one expects…, and the end result that puts the crown on your work. Creativity, playfulness, communication, imagination - all of which you will need in this great party game where the story can only be limited by your own imagination. Move the threads skillfully and be the best storyteller on your team!

The game lasts for 10 rounds. The first 9 rounds have 3 phases, Inspiration, Writing, and Evaluation.
In the Inspiration phase, we draw 2 characters, 2 dramas and 2 end cards to the playing field.
In the Writing phase, each player thinks about which combination of 3 cards they think could make the most interesting story. It is important that you choose one of each category.

Everyone will write on their page the letter combinations (for example, BAA) of the selected pages next to the current round number.
In the first three rounds, the text of the selected Character Cards is recorded, in rounds 4-6 the text of the selected Drama card, and in rounds 7-9 the text of the End Card.

In the Rating phase, players receive points for each of their teammates who have selected the same letter combination for their story. If exactly the same combination is written, everyone gets 4 points, if only the first 2 letters match, 2 points, if only the first letter matches, 1 point goes. No points are awarded if the first letter of the letter combination does not match anyone.

The tenth round is the Synopsis. In this round, we do not put new cards on the game board, but the Inspiration phase takes place from the texts of the previously selected cards. So in the Inspiration phase, we write the final story from the text of the 3-3-3 inspiration cards previously written on the scorecard.
As everyone completes in a row, tell the Final Story one after the other. Don’t forget to give the story a title.
After telling the Final Story, players secretly give each other points. Everyone can split 7 points among the other players, we give the most to the one who we think invented the best story.
After telling the story, everyone adds up the victory points earned during the 9+1 rounds.

Ask your friends about 90's Turkish pop culture. One person becomes the judge and reads the card. Who ever answers first gets the point. Most Points wins the game!

—user summary

Kavga, polemik, basitlik, skandal...Hepsi bir kutuda bir araya geldi! Åžokopop ekibi, siz ve kankeytolarÄ±nÄ±zÄ±n eÄŸlenerek magazin bilgilerinizi yarÄ±ÅŸtÄ±rmanÄ±z için kolay, orta ve zor olmak üzere toplam 200 soru çÄ±kardÄ±. Size de oynamak ve sürpriz joker kartlarla uzmanlÄ±ÄŸÄ±nÄ±zÄ± kanÄ±tlamak kaldÄ±. ÅžansÄ±nÄ±z bol olsun!

—description from the publisher

This game is a Yahtzee variant for kids.

The dice contain icons instead of numbers, and special dice combinations need to be played.

The game is designed with the "Olchis", a green family of creatures designed by Erhard Dietl.

A typical roll and move type promotional board game. Published to celebrate 50 years of Homann Margarine.

The players take turns to roll and move. They start at space 1. The first to reach space 50 wins the game. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The game board shows the production process of "Homann Margarine".

Pin 2 Win! combines Bible trivia with 7 life skill categories (camping, health & fitness, recreation, world missions, arts & crafts, Bible facts, nature).

Players roll the dice to move around the track. They must answer a questions in the subject of the space they land on, collecting merits tokens and pins.

The first player get to the collect seven merit tokens and a pin wins the game!

ãã—ã¦æ·±æµ·é­šã¯ï¼ã«ãªã‚‹ (Soshite Shinkaigyo ha 0 ninaru) is a card game from Japan, and means something like 'And The Deep Sea Fish Becomes Zero'. Players are trying to get their tableau of cards down to the lowest total. If a top and bottom row card match, those two equal zero. At the end of the game, the lowest total score wins.

The deck is numbered 1 to 8, with one 1, two 2s, three 3s and so on. Each number is a different sea creature.

Players have a tableau of six cards face-down in two rows of three. Two are turned up and the highest total starts. On their turn, a player draws either from the deck or from the discard pile. The player then uses the drawn card to replace an existing card in their tableau. The new card goes face-up, the old card goes face-up to the discard. If the player drew from the draw pile, they can discard it instead.

In this way, cards gradually get turned up. The game ends when either the draw deck is exhausted, or a player has all six cards face-up. The totals are calculated, and the lowest total wins.

However, the game has certain twists. For example, the 4 card is actually -4. The 5 card forces another player to turn up a card, possibly ending the sooner. Sharks must be placed as shown on the shark card, and so on.

Because there are more high number cards, it is harder to get the score down. But players have more chances to match pairs and make them go to zero.
user summary

Multiplayer game system, inspired by some MTG mechanics, with heavy adaptation to a hex grid system like Advanced Squad Leader.

Each player controls a group of units, heroes and monsters trying to exploit every stat and ability in order to overcome the enemy group.

Depending on the game mode, you win by controlling certain parts of the map, or by destroying the enemy commander, or even by simply destroying every unit in the enemy group.

—description from the designer

For several years you have been experimenting with nanotechnological materials, in particular with graphene, you manage to discover an efficient way to produce it, you get the capital to start a business and you choose to focus on the European Union markets... but you are not the only one! The next few years will be key to position itself.

In a first phase, the participants will choose the countries in which they will initially invest and decide on their headquarters.

They will only be able to stay in a country, which manages to position itself better in the market, after checking the return on the initial investment (which is determined with a minigame of skill and fortune, the CT or coin toss).

Then the actions phase begins, where each player can perform one action per round, such as reinvesting in an already dominated market, conquering a free market, or attacking a market dominated by another player (all will be defined with the CT).

The final score is determined at the end of the fifth round, the participants will receive points according to the initial investment, the countries they dominate, according to the final value and their sizes, in addition to the bonus for maintaining the main venue or those that may have been obtained by a launch in the Kanchis sector (seven).


Desde hace varios años estás experimentando con materiales nanotecnológicos, en particular con el grafeno, lográs descubrir una forma eficiente de producirlo, consigues el capital para lanzarte a emprender y eliges concentrarte en los mercados de la Unión Europea... pero no eres el único! Los próximos años serán clave para posicionarse.

En una primera fase, los participantes elegirán los países en los que invertirán inicialmente y decidirán cuál es su sede central.

Sólo podrán quedarse en un país, quien logre posicionarse mejor en el mercado, luego de comprobar el rendimiento de la inversión inicial (que se determina con un minijuego de habilidad y fortuna, el LM o lanzamiento de monedas).

Luego comienza la fase de acciones, en donde cada jugador podrá realizar una acción por ronda, como reinvertir en un mercado ya dominado, conquistar a un mercado libre, o atacar a un mercado dominado por otro jugador (todas se definirán con el LM).

El puntaje final se determina al finalizar la quinta ronda, los participantes recibirán puntos según la inversión inicial, los países que dominen, de acuerdo al valor final y los tamaños del mismo, además del bonus por mantener la sede principal o de los que pudieran haber sido obtenidos por algún lanzamiento en el sector Kanchis (siete).

Veredicto is a fun board game, created in Argentina, where you have to defend cases and convince other players that what you say is true, in order to win!

It's time to give your “Verdict”!!! All participants must use their ingenuity, strategy and audacity to defend a statement, whether it is true or false, and persuade the other players with arguments to win, within the dramatization of a trial where the participants will play the roles of lawyers and jury.

Players must advance and add positions to win round after round each case as lawyers or by getting their verdicts right as a jury, until someone manages to win the game.

The game is innovative and contains a large dose of entertainment because the players learn from each case and have fun watching the lawyers argue in each case. In turn, the participants test their knowledge, in a unique dynamic where everyone plays all the time.

How to play?

The plot of the game is novel and captivating. Players take on the role of lawyers and - indicated by a card - must argue for the truth or falsity of a statement, trying to convince the other players (the "jury") to lean towards their defense.

It's a game for 3 to 6 players or teams where you'll be a lawyer and you'll have to defend unusual cases and convince the rest that your argument is true in order to beat your opponent. The objective of the game is to win as many cases as possible to move up in your career before the rest do. Each lawyer must defend a position regarding an affirmation, convincing the rest that what he says is correct.

Imagine a world where you are no longer the top of the food chain. A world where society has fallen, governments cease to function, and countries fall into chaos. A new primeval world where the surviving members of humankind must band together in order to fight for their existence over scarce resources.
 A new world filled with hungry, feral dinosaurs.
 This is the world of The Carniverse. Will you lead your team of survivors to victory against their foes? Or will they become just another snack for the new gods of our planet?

This is a scenario-driven miniatures skirmish game played on a 3'x3' surface with terrain features. Each player controls a team of survivors battling against other teams of survivors for resources while trying to not get eaten by dinosaurs. Each team has specific skills and abilities. They are created based on available Resource Points.
Each game is divided up into five phases that make up a single game turn when combined. 
The phases that make up a single turn are:

     The Dino Phase
     The Movement Phase
     The Shooting Phase
     The Melee Phase
     The End Phase


When the last phase is finished, the cycle begins again until any victory or loss conditions for the scenario are met.

—description from the publisher

You are a fly stuck in a computer!

Roll dice to move about the motherboard to collect Energy. Use that energy to power up the computer components (cpu, graphics card, etc.) and use capacitors to strategically assemble the components on your motherboard for extra points, but watch out! Resistors can pop and you can cause a short circuit and get Zapped!

Can you fully assemble your Motherboard before you get fried?! Or get some of your techy friends and compete to build you motherboard or varying boards and score the most points!

—description from the designer

It is time to conquer a new frontier. As global overseer you have ambitious plans for your expansion into the galaxy, but space is large and there are many contenders to deal with. From the peaceful Alliance to the insect-like Swarm or the warrior race Kthuani. Do you have what it takes to emerge victorious from the  galactic power struggle?

Ascent is a solitaire, 4x, sci-fi, roll and write game in which you must explore your local sector, discover and lay claim to new systems and their resources, defeat your enemies in battle and trade with your allies (or destroy them too).

The game is played over a series of turns divided into 6 phases. During each turn you’ll gather resources, explore space and colonize star systems, construct new structures to progress your colonies, improve your armada and advance your political agenda.

Win the game by efficiently managing your commodities and time in order to pursue one of the 3 different, species-specific, winning conditions (Goals).

Once you complete any one of your goals the game ends and, optionally, you can determine your final score.

Will you be remembered as an all-powerful leader? A grand merchant? A warmonger? A political genius? Or something entirely different?

—description from the designer

Two ten-sided dice determine both the initial placements of player tokens and the placements of Gadget Cards throughout the game. Setup takes less than a minute and gameplay is simple and fast-paced. 2-8 players scramble around a 10x10 board collecting Gadget Cards that can alter the layout of the board, enhance their own abilities, change existing conditions, or - most importantly - attack other players. Attacks remove one of three "Life Gizmos" from a player. Players battle until only one person has any Life Gizmos left.

During a turn, players will move around the board collecting Gadget Crates. They can play Actions, spawn new Gadget cards, or move any player token that does not have Life Gizmos. At the end of their turn, they can Attack other players, removing one Life Gizmo from every target they hit.

When a player is reduced to 0 Life Gizmos, they can no longer collect or use Gadget Cards, but can still move around the board and damage other players. If they manage to get to a player who still has Life Gizmos, they steal one of them and can continue gathering and playing Gadget Cards as normal. Gameplay continues until Life Gizmos have been removed from all but one player.

—description from the designer

The King is a formidable ruler, whose strength and cunning have not been matched in a generation. But he is away on a diplomatic visit to another realm... now is your chance to seize the throne! 

Take control of his legion troops and he will be ill equipped to stand against you.

Master the dark arts and summon a demon and he dare not oppose you.

Infiltrate his court and turn his own advisors against him and he will be powerless to stand in your way.

But, if he returns before you accomplish one of those things, kiss your ambitions good-bye.

Will you have the best reputation among the guilds when the king returns?

Usurpers is a worker placement game where each of your workers have a type and a level. Many of the worker spaces care about one, the other, or both of those attributes. Blocking is a big dynamic in worker placement games, and in this one you are allowed to use a space as long as your worker is at least tied for the highest level there when you place it. This means there's not as much blocking at the beginning of the game, but as players level their workers up, blocking (and therefor placement tension) becomes more and more of a thing.

—description from the designer

Game of Trumps is a trick-taking card game for four players.  It is played in partnerships, but what sets this game apart is that players do not know who their partners are at the beginning of the round!  The partnerships are revealed over the course of the round through card play.

The deck consists of four suits: Circles, Squares, Triangles, and Trumps.  The Trump suit has cards numbered 1 to 14, while the other three suits are numbered 1 to 6.

There is no bidding, and play proceeds like most trick-taking games, with one player leading a suit and other players following if they can.  Certain cards are worth points if they are taken as part of a trick.

The player or players that have the top two trump cards are on one team, and the rest of the players are on the other.  This is not revealed before the round, but through normal card play.

At the end of the round, each player scores points based on how their team did during the round.  The first player to 10 points wins!

Strategy game for two players.

The object of Sneaky is to be the first player to capture all five of your opponent's checkers.

The game has two dice, one of movement (from 1 to 3) and another Furtive dice, empty on five sides and with an eye on the sixth. The player will roll the dice secretly and will be able to lie about the result, being able to play a "bluff".

-------------------------------------------------------------------Juego de estrategia para dos jugadores.
El objetivo de Furtivo es ser el primer jugador en capturar las cinco fichas del oponente.
El juego dispone de dos dados, uno de movimiento (de 1 a 3) y otro dado Furtivo, vacío en cinco caras y con un ojo en la sexta.
El jugador tirará los dados de forma secreta y podrá mentir sobre el resultado, pudiendo jugar un “farol”.

Through the use of clues the reader and Lieutenant John Milton Schwab of the Florida Police attempt to solve the mystery surrounding the death by poisoning of a wealthy British businessman.

Crime Dossier 2 of a 4 book set that was an early progenitor of the modern mystery suspect / cold case tabletop games.

You're having a summer party in the garden. A few friends arrive early in the afternoon to help with the preparations: Beer tables are dragged, tablecloths laid out and space made for the drinks. In one corner of the garden, however, a loud competition breaks out over who will hang the most beautiful string of lights. Who will hang the coolest fairy lights at your garden party?

All cards show three power lines with light bulbs and lanterns of different colors hanging from them. You place one of them in front of you as your own starting card. The rest of the cards are placed in the center of the table. Look at them carefully, because it's all about speed! Once you've all placed one hand flat on the table, you're ready to go.

You grab cards with only one hand at a time, as fast as you can, and place them on your string of lights. Also make sure that the power lines are not always straight. This can get lost in the heat of the moment. You can also flip cards, because maybe the back side will be more useful. But you have to put your hand flat on the table again before you can return to the action.

Whoever has laid the required length first, depending on the number of players, gives the signal to the others to come to the end. Now you can see who has really conjured up the best string of lights:

The more light bulbs and lanterns of the same color follow each other in a line, the more points the chain of lights earns you. The lanterns are particularly valuable because, unlike light bulbs, they also count individually and even double the point value if they are part of a row. When your arms are unknotted and your eyes are no longer spinning, you can immediately start the next round.

It's game 17 of the series "Die Kleinen Feinen".

Come Mr. Osbon, this is not the time for prayer!
--Admiral Farragut, to flag officer Osbon, who was kneeling on the USS Hartford’s main deck preparing a shell fuse during the battle of Forts Jackson and Philip.

No Time For Prayer details the battles for the port and city of New Orleans; Head of Passes and Forts Jackson and St. Philip.

The battles to take control of New Orleans were not easy ones. Can you do as well or better than your historical counterpart?

Players will also need one standard deck of playing cards, a six-sided die and one ten sided die to play the game. A die roll of 0 is read as 10 and not zero.

The Penobscot Bay off the coast of Maine produces a yearly bounty of saltwater fish, shellfish, and lobsters. This solitaire roll-and-write game lets players become commercial fishers, seeking the largest and best catches of these valuable seafoods. It’s a risky endeavor, requiring proper timing, thoughtful management of your resources, and a bit of old-fashioned good luck.

Choose your location, roll your dice, and see what you've caught. If you succeed, sell your catch strategically to earn top dollar. If you don't succeed, use your failures wisely, to improve your operation for next season.

This is a solitaire, print-and-play, roll-and-write design. The game comes with rulebook, map sheet, and record sheet. The only other bits required are three dice: one each in green, red, and blue.

The game takes about 45 minutes (15 minutes for each of three rounds), and is appropriate for ages 10 and up.

4 levels - 8 categories - 32 important places of chess - 512 questions: Test your knowledge concerning the history, the rules, the board and its pieces and much more around on the most popular board games in the world!

The game board shows a map of Europe with 32 places that are significant to the history of chess. Each place is displayed with a playing field containing one of eight category symbols. The starting point is Madrid, the location of the first European chess tournament in 1575. The goal is to get to Tromsö, the venue of the 2014 Chess Olympiade.

The cards are divided into eight categories: Peculiarities – Openings – Mate in 1 – Rules – Game Board & Figures – Chess Lexicon – Timeless Beauty – Quiz. Every category is positioned on the board game with its own symbol and colour. On each question card, you will find questions for four different difficulty levels: Pawn –> Knight –> Rook –> Queen. The questions are ordered from easiest to most difficult, so there is an opportunity for everyone to be involved.

Bonnie & Clyde, Love and Death is first and foremost a solo game that can also be played as a duo, where the goal is to find the romantic end that the couple dreamed of.

Along this road trip, you will have to choose the right actions to survive, stick up banks or stores, but also keep an eye on the gas tank and the state of your vehicle, and, of course, outrun the cops, who will only get better and better at tracking you down.

At the beginning of the game, you choose from four levels of difficulty and set out on the first country road.

Each turn represents a day divided into three phases: Morning, Afternoon, and Night.

During the game, you have to manage your resource and situation gauges. Some of them can lead to your death, such as not having any food or ammunition during a shootout; others can lead to defeat, such as having a love gauge at zero, which would lead to the separation of the couple. It is therefore important to fulfill the victory conditions before triggering any defeat condition.

In easy mode, the goal is to finish your run with a shoutout in a farmhouse, with two bank loot and your love gauge raised to the maximum before the police — or someone — kill Bonnie or Clyde.

Celebrate 30 years of funk! ToeJam and Earl take it to the tabletop in this brand-new Rogue like Party Board Game, where players can experience new and different levels every session!

Be the first player to find and collect 3 Rocketship pieces - while not letting the Earthlings trip you up! Players roll dice and move along the track collecting rocket ship pieces and presents. Every present is different and may just give you the winning edge!

ToeJam & Earl Tabletop Remix is fully compatible with Yooka-Laylee and Mutant Mudds Game Decks board games! Mix and match for some truly funky results!

TropeQuest pokes fun at everyone's favorite sci-fi and fantasy stereotypes and puts them literally into the hands of the players, who attempt to turn a pile of genre fiction cliches into a workable narrative. It's a creative, collaborative game with a lighthearted competitive element that uses cards and a board to make it fun and easy for players to improvise an original story. Best of all, it generates a unique tale each and every time it's played.

The board provides the story arc, a plot map that packs as many cliched scenarios and overwrought plot twists as possible into fifteen squares. The deck brings the setting... a library of genre tropes and oblique pop culture references to tickle the imaginations of geeks and laypersons alike. Players and encouraged to mix, match, and try out new combinations.

After a deck of tropes and a plot board are chosen, players are each dealt a hand of cards and take turns being the Narrator. The Narrator reads the prompt on the next available square and chooses a card from a pool of trope cards submitted by adjacent players (plus one random from the deck) to finish the prompt. While this may yield some hilarious results, the Narrator's work has not yet begun! Next, the Narrator "sells" the scene by elaborating, tying up loose ends, spicing it up a bit. Afterwards, the players redraw cards, the player whose card was picked draws an extra one, and the next player becomes the Narrator. Rinse and repeat until all fifteen squares have been played and the story has reached its thrilling climax.

So, the story is over. What was the point of it all? Well, in a way, the goal of the game is to laugh, have fun, and tell a quirky story together. However, in another, more mathematical and literal way, the goal of the game is to win by having more cards than anyone else at the end of the game. But winning also comes with great responsibility! After the gloating is over, the winner then chooses their favorite scene in the story Narrated by another player. That player then becomes the Chosen One, Master of Tropes and The Uber-Winner of that round of TropeQuest.

It's spring 1927, and while Americans dance the Charleston and drink bootlegged liquor, the Mississippi Delta faces a flood of epic proportions. If battered river levees collapse, everything important to you will be washed away.

Rising Waters is a co-operative board game built around area control, set collection, and variable player power mechanics where players experience life through the lens of African American plight. In the game, you will confront two forces – racism from white landowners and the power of nature. Persevere by drawing on your community’s courage and strength from your family, church, music, farming, and education. Can you manage the rising waters to stay alive?

Rising Waters is a 2-4 player game about the strength of community, methods of resistance, and the struggle against nature suitable for both classroom use and casual play from Central Michigan University Press. There are many ways to mod the game for replayability, including Community Goal Cards and individual Character Goals. There are easy and hard versions of the game, and it can even be played as a two-handed solo game! Rising Waters is played on a hex-based map of the Mississippi River and surrounding lands based on the area around Vicksburg, Mississippi. The game runs over a series of rounds representing different weeks during the flood, when players have opportunities to work cooperatively and individually to save their homes, families, and communities. During the flood, work together to keep your family and neighbors alive by minimizing losses during the flood. Players must also negotiate the arbitrary demands of white landowners.

Yet African Americans weren't solely victims in the 1927 flood – as always, they maintained a sense of agency and sources of power to survive. In the game, this comes from the Community cards, which include blues, farm animals, church, garden, family, and education cards. The cards help players upgrade their abilities during the game as well as resist racism. Rising Waters serves as a powerful illustration of the difficulty of African American lives in the Jim Crow South. Through the game, players will be able to have challenging conversations about the endemic nature of racism and how it complicates life during a crisis. If players keep below the maximum level of losses for a certain number of rounds, they've survived the worst of the flood and win the game!

Within Walls is a Paranoia driven hidden traitor game with social deduction elements set in the early 20th century horror setting. The gameplay is heavily focused on player interaction with  intuitive rules that are designed merely as a catalyst for player interaction and serve the purpose to define available options.
You are agents sent to investigate an incident in a local sanatorium. Upon arrival on the scene you realize there is an impostor among you.
Your goal is to gather as much information as possible while making sure all witnesses remain alive for further questioning.

Move through the Story by drawing Event cards and playing them during your turn in accordance with your agenda, the mandatory play means you will be faced with several bad choices - in this game most choices are bad. As the story advances more and more clues are found about the traitor, however reaching the end of any story Act with the traitor alive means that the agents lose the game. The traitor(s) must be stopped before reaching the completion of his mission. A unique story progress board is used to mark the progress of the team as a whole while individual Mind sheets follow players' descent into inevitable madness.
The game ends either when the Agents win by discovering and eliminating the Traitor or when the Traitor wins by either eliminating all Agents or reaching the end of the story and completing his goal.
The special 2 player game mode keeps the suspense, social deduction elements and paranoia with only minor rule changes.
Included is one Investigation focus die made of wood, as imperfect as the world you are playing in and unique,, again.. as this world.

The player on offense and the player on defense each plays a card face down. Both players then flip their cards over at the same time revealing the selected plays. Once a card is played, it is discarded in a separate pile which becomes the discard pile. After each play advance the down counter to the next down unless there is a first down conversion, a scoring play, or a turnover.

The game is played in two “halves”. A half is over when there are no more cards available and neither player has a card in his hand. A half will take from 30 to 45 minutes. When the half is over, shuffle all the Offense, Defense, and Special Teams decks. Each player draws 5 cards to start the second half.

The Game is over at the end of the second half. The player with the most points wins. For a shorter game, play 1 half.

A rotating Diss-Master reads a card out loud to the group (for example: Who's the worst gift-giver? The chronic over-sharer? The pickiest eater?). Everyone else writes down their answer on their dry-erase boards, and then it's up to the Diss-Master to pick their favorite answer— after reading all the responses out loud, of course!

Memoroute is a memory game which moles compete to open new underground paths. Unlike other memory games, you don't take two matching tiles, instead, your mole moves to a hole next to the matching tile that you opened secondly. Most of the times, you have to match several tile sets (and move your mole) until your mole finally reaches to a hole you are to connect.

On your turn, you select one of the face-down flower tiles adjacent to your mole pawn and flip it to the flower side, and then select another face-down flower tile from anywhere on the board. If the two tiles match, move your mole next to one of the holes adjacent to the second tile.

You keep having your turn until you fail to find two matching tiles. And in anytime during your turn, if your mole gets to a hole indicated on your mission card, you flip that card and continue your turn.

When you fail, you reset the game board by flipping all the opened tile and pass your turn.  When a player flips all four mission cards, the player wins!

Moles, moles! Find the holes and stick the poles!

The personal branding game, MY BRAND, is developed based on the 5-personality type of 'CEO Brand Big 5'. This theory is based on the "Brand Personality Big 5", developed by Professor Jennifer Aaker of Standford University.

Players become brand managers, and through three consecutive games that they will play, they will help others and themselves to learn about their current brands and the brands that they are to persue.

Game 1
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Pick a card from the hand and introduce themselves using the brand card.
Players vote two players who presented the best.
Take the card and make your personal 'Brand Archive' pile.

Game 2 
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Pick two card from the hand and open them on the table. 
Then players tell stories about the strengths they have. 
The other players offer each narrator a card from their hands.
The narrator takes two cards among them. 
Send those two cards along with two other cards you previously places on the table to your 'Brand Archive'.

Game 3
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Players take turn become a presenter. The presenter opens a Question card. 
Question cards have questions like: 
'What is the cover of your autobiography that you've published 20 years later like?'
'What is the feed you are uploading, 5 years later, as a social media influencer like?
All players place a card face-down. The presenter gather the cards from the other players and add more card from the deck to make a total of 7 Brand cards. Shuffle them and open those cards in a single line. 
Players secretly select two cards they think most accurately represent the presenter related to the question. 
Then place tokens on those two cards. If more than two players selected the same cards, those players each gain points as many as the number of tokens on it. 
Sent three cards which have the most vote along with your own card to your 'Brand Archive.'

Players gain points as they play each game, they get points from the vote they get and the cards selected by other players, etc. Whoever has the highest score after three games becomes the best brand manager and wins the game.

After the game, you can examine and draw your brand in graph at the back of your sheet. 
It will visually tell you your current brand and the brand to pursue.

Wild West Exodus is a dynamic, fast-paced tabletop miniatures game pitting a cast of heroic characters against each other in a brutal world - very much a twisted reflection of our own. In the twilight years of the Nineteenth Century, mankind is perched upon a new age of discovery and enlightenment.

However, humanity’s greed and ambition have created a Dystopian Age where nations clash and the threat of war forever lingers. We must remember that all is not lost. In Wild West Exodus the bravery and actions of individuals on the frontier can still forge legends and change the world.

Showdown at Retribution is a two-player starter set designed to give you a comprehensive introduction to the savage Wild West in the Dystopian Age. Containing dozens of fantastically detailed Warcradle miniatures, the full third edition rulebook, quick start guide to help you get going straight away and much more - this hefty boxed set is an easy way to explore the game and start your hobby adventure.

—description from the publisher

GAME IDEA
The game is played in 12 rounds in which the dice fall anew each time. All see the same result but everybody from another perspective. Each player always tries to find the best scoring category for him. 
But attention: 
Each category is available only once per game! So far so easy, if only the dice would not always disappear under the cup again so fast … Who has grasped the best result in the short term? And in which category would eventually have been more to achieve?

GOAL OF THE GAME
The player with the highest total score in the end wins the DICE CUP-Challenge!

PREPARATION
Put the dice in the cup. Each player gets a scoring sheet and a pen – and writes down his name on the up right line intended for it. Now a starting player is chosen and off we go!

GAME PLAY
The starting player starts rolling the dice but still everybody plays always simultaneously.
Each round consists of 8 steps:

     Put all dice in the cup.
     Your hand above it and shake it well.
     Turn around the cup with the dice and overthrow it on the table so all dice are hidden underneath the cup.
     Lift up the cup for about 3 seconds (to measure the time, slowly say the following slogan: „Lift the cup – eyes up“). The dice must be clearly visible for everybody for the same amount of time.
     Then the cup is put over the dice again carefully so that they are not turned over accidentally.
     Now each player sets a cross in the little circle of the box in the category he wants to value. You can use your hand as a sight screen. Once the cross is set it may not be changed anymore.
     When everybody is ready the player lifts the cup again and puts it aside so the dice result is visible for all players again.
     Now everybody values his result and writes the points in the corresponding field (Example Kim see valuation). Pass the cup on in clockwise direction. The next round starts. Important: Sometimes the dice lie on top of each other. Then the dice roll must be repeated immediately!


VALUATION AND EXAMPLES

     Who has chosen „count fours only“ in the upper part, multiplies the number of fours with 4 (of fives with 5, of sixes with 6). E.g. three time 4: 3 x 4 = 12 points 
     Who has set a cross for a colour, e.g. „blue“, in the middle part, only counts the eyes of the two dice in this colour and notes down the sum. Scoring of Kim 5 + 6 = 11 points 
     Who has chosen „double“, may note down 10 points for each „double“ of the same colour. E.g. one „double“ (red) = 10 points
     Who has marked „all ones, twos and threes“, adds all dice pips which show ones, twos and threes. E.g. 1 + 1 + 1 + 2 + 2 + 3 + 3 = 13 points 
     Who has chosen „DICE CUP“, adds the pips of all dice and


notes down the sum. E.g. 1 + 1 + 1 + 2 + 2 + 3 + 3 + 4 + 4 + 4 +5 + 6 = 36 points After each valuation the respective selected category * The dot next to the red square is used for better is of course dropped for the current game.

END OF THE GAME
The game ends after 12 played rounds. In the last round the cup can be left aside after the third playing step, and the last valuation (for the respective individual last category) is done at once. Afterwards every player adds the points of the three parts on his scoring sheet, transmits the sum into the fields provided for this purpose and calculates the total amount.
The player with the highest total amount wins the DICE CUP-Challenge!

VARIATIONS:
The „Eyes up time“ may vary as the players like or by experience. Pro players can shorten the time to 2 seconds, for example. Beginners and younger players may extend it. All players always have the same length of time available … It is also much fun to play several games simultaneously. The players have two or more columns in each category to fill in and value.

Have fun playing!

A small postcard game on the landing operations by the US and New Zealand forces on Nissan Island, the Green Islands, on February 15, 1944 (operation Squarepeg).

The game features a standard "I go-you go" mechanics but with unlimited movement subject to fatigue (the more you move, the higher the possibility of being fatigued). The NZ player must conquer the objective hex or eliminate all Japanese units in 5 turns; otherwise, the Japanese player wins.

The game is called Iwoká: La Tierra sin Mal (The land without evil). It is played on the space of a board, between two players: one will be the Tupi-Guarani aboriginal people, and the other the viceroy with his army. But, while the game is played, the competitors -due to the characteristics of entertainment- will be invited to walk the path of historical knowledge; they will be able to know the circumstances of the time; the rituals, legends and cosmogonies of the aborigines; They will be able to delve into the war iconography of the time, the weapons and ships of the conquerors, their war tactics, etc. And, also, some continental geography.

Two players or teams can play the Iwoká from the age of 9. One will be the Tupi-Guarani people, and the other will be the viceroy and his army. It is played with green and brown chips, in circular movements. On the board the most important place is the center called Arete (the promised land of the aboriginal people). The viceroy is occupying this sacred place: his objective will be to leave through four paths or exit points, from the center to the outside of the board, and flee by ship with the stolen riches. In the escape, he will be protected by his army.

The Tupi-Guarani, who are around the Arete, have the mission of preventing the viceroy and his army from escaping with his riches. How do they prevent the flight of the conquerors? Enclosing them with tokens. The army can be "eaten" with the tokens and eliminated, but the viceroy must be locked up with the tokens.

The invaders win if the viceroy reaches any of the four starting squares, and flee with the riches. The natives win if the viceroy is trapped between tiles.

Your challenge in Pyramiland is to rid yourself of the balls in your collection first.

To set up, place up to sixty pegs in the holes of the wooden game board to create the field of play, and give each player the same number of wooden balls. On a turn, you place a ball on the playing area, then you can play again if you can place a ball so that it touches the ball just placed while also being on a higher level. You can continue to take extra turns so long as you can do this.

When you place on the lowest level, your ball must be supported by four wooden pegs. On the second level and higher, your ball just needs to be supported by other balls, but due to the layout of the pegs, not all of the balls will be in identical rows, so you likely won't have a clean, regular-shaped pyramid as you build to higher levels.

Whoever places their final ball first wins. If a player cannot place a ball or knocks a ball from the pyramid, including one just placed, the game ends, that player loses, and whoever has the fewest balls remaining wins.

How well do you really know the USA? This game will vastly improve your knowledge while introducing the thrill of competition and a great deal of fun between friends and family.

Each player gets two state sheets - five states per sheet. The first player that fills ONE sheet wins the game. Player gets cards by either competing with facts (Area, Population, Highest point, Avg. temperatre) or either wining challenges. Challenge can be called by player that's on turn and holding a weak card - lower fact values and is decided by dice roll.

This game that has the purpose of making visible and spreading the leading role that Latin American women have had in the construction of a different world, in the struggle to defend the rights of the oppressed peoples and classes.

Transforming in each of its steps the history of the entire continent, breaking barriers, in no hurry to lose calm until patriarchy and capitalism fall.

It is three games in one, or three modes to play with the same cards.

The first mode "Allies", each player must summon Allies to add more voices and defeat the Patriarchy.

The deck of cards is taken and they will be revealed one at a time.

On their turn, each player can choose to take refuge with their Allies, or stay in the streets to gather more voices, but be careful, since the same deck can leave Violence cards, which will stop us in the fight for freedom.

Violence cards include, Repression, Disappearance, Indifference, Capitalism, and Patriarchy. If one of these cards appears, we will be at risk, but we can continue fighting, if a second card appears, we will lose all the Allies that we had gathered that round.

The second mode "United" is a very dynamic game in real time, where we will try to collect all the cards of the same fighter as quickly as possible, to get all the characteristics of each one, and to put an end to the disinformation of their stories. .

We will have 7 different cards in our hands, and we will have to exchange cards with other players, with the only limitation that all the cards delivered must be from the same Fighter. The player who manages to collect the 7 cards of the same Fighter first, will be the winner.

Finally, the third modality "Abya Yala", is a cooperative game where we will try to reconstruct the story. For which we will have to put together a timeline ordering from smallest to largest the year in which the women who have fought to defend the rights of our peoples throughout the continent were born.

But with a twist, since we will play with our cards upside down, so that we can only see the back of our cards, but we can see all the cards in hand of our partners.

In turn, we will have to give clues to the other players about the cards in their hand, and thus be able, together, to put together the correct time lines.

A lot of memory, a lot of commitment, in a beautifully illustrated game, with great quality components, which will help us become aware and build knowledge for the construction of a different, fairer and more inclusive society.

Cooperative game. Scour the neighborhood to find what each project calls for before time runs out. The challenges will be proposing different complexities. The ticking clock will be a very important factor to add excitement and fun!

Olivia and Cukito's adventure is the ninth title that we have produced from El Espejo, and it is of great importance to us as it is our first specifically cooperative proposal. It is an invitation to the game for early childhood, with a neighborhood theme where we seek to work on the issue of waste, trying to problematize the idea of â€‹â€‹"individual environmentalism" (see section), emphasizing the importance of cooperative work and proposing as a challenge build works or "manufacturable" objects from said waste. With the premise of promoting group work, throughout the game the challenges intensify in difficulty and in the forms of communication between the players.

Olivia, along with Cukito and her friends, are thinking about what to do with so much waste that is scattered around their neighborhood. It occurred to them to put together Projects to recycle, turning some waste into useful objects or reusing them in different ways. To achieve this, they must move at full speed, locker by locker, lifting those elements that serve to complete the projects.

A game where laughter and creativity come from the tip of your tongue.

Teams are assembled and the game begins. When it is your turn, you have to give clues so that your classmates guess the secret word (the one that is underlined), but without saying any of the words that appear on the card (or their family of words). WATCH OUT! That the opposing team will be monitoring you.

Questions related to daily life, trades, domestic tasks, popular knowledge, ancestral knowledge... all this and much more will accompany us on this path of fun and learning.

Caminando is a quiz game, with varied dynamics where other types of knowledge and skills are rewarded that are not associated (like most quiz games) with academic knowledge. Questions referring to daily life where the knowledge "that plays" is that which we have acquired at work, from grandmothers, on the street, in domestic chores, in the neighbourhood. Caminando proposes us to play from other ways of asking about many kinds of knowledge. Because here all knowledge is valid.

A memory card game where a number of cards are placed face up in a circle and players must memorize them. A tree, flags, ants, the world and an infinity of beautiful images. You will have to remember where each one is to take the cards!

The players take turns to roll and move. They start with their Steamship at space 1 in Ludwigshafen. The first player to reach space 55 (Köln) wins the game. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

It’s time to make your return to Rattler Gulch!  In 1849, gold was found in the river that runs just North of town and prospectors from all over the country headed to the boom town to make their fortune.  Many of these miners found nothing but despair, but a few made out like bandits.  One of them was Mr. George Duncan and he became so wealthy that it made him quite the target for thieves.  Someone in town made off with his entire score one night and he is offering you quite the reward to figure out whodunnit and return it to him.  There are 3 missions in this massive game.

Interview the suspects in town and discover their secrets.  Pan for gold and examine the scene of the crime.  Prepare to name the thief and recover the lost gold!  Just remember that with this much money involved, the culprit won’t go down without a fight.

About Escape the Crate escape room boxes:
Each box has over a dozen unique puzzles which all fit the theme. Every item in the box has a purpose and will help you escape in time. Clue are hidden everywhere and in this game you need to think inside the box. Each box is a complete story.

These missions can be challenging and it is very possible you won't escape before the time limit. You can always reset the game using our instructions or you can continue playing past the time limit to see the mission to completion.
Every challenge you will face will have a set of hints, which you can choose to reveal when your team needs them. If you are completely stumped, even after the hints, the solution is also provided.

Note: You will need a fully charged computer or mobile device to play this escape room.

It is the archaeological find of the century!  The fabled lost “Temple of the Crocodile” has been unearthed deep in the jungles and we are sending you in to investigate the find!  It is rumored that buried deep inside the temple, there is a secret.  One that might change mankind as we know it.  EMIT tried to keep the discovery a secret, but our arch-rival, Mr. X, seems to have hacked our systems and is hot on our heels.  He has sent his own agents to the temple to challenge you to the find.  TWO games await you within this adventure.  Find your way through the temple, discovering secret passages in an attempt to gain access to the treasure.  Then, try to find a way to escape the temple, as a series of fiendish traps are set against you.  That isn’t it, though.  Your team will be presented with a choice at the beginning of the game.  Play together as one team to beat Mr. X’s agents and find the treasure together as a team OR split into two competing groups.  Some players may have the opportunity to join Mr. X and challenge the remainder of the group to see who gets to the treasure first…  Will you defeat Mr. X as a team… or will you turn against each other in a chance for eternal glory?

Note: You will need a fully charged computer or mobile device to play this escape room.

Two murder mysteries await in this massive adventure!  The year is 1928 and Prohibition is the law of the land.  Behind the hidden door to the Blind Hog Saloon, however, drinks are pouring, gambling is rampant, and men and women dance the night away to the Charleston.  The owner of the speakeasy, Arthur “Goldie” Nickels, rules the shadows and has made thousands by smuggling and selling alcohol…until he was found murdered.  There were only a few suspects around him at the time of his death and it is up to you to find the entrance to the speakeasy, interview the suspects, and to solve the crime.  Unfortunately for you, however, there are multiple weapons, motives, and killers to choose from.  Even more than that… Goldie is not the only person who will be murdered in the speakeasy tonight.  Another murder sets the scene for the second mystery in the box… one where you appear to be the leading suspect.  Solve both murders before you find yourself framed for the crime of the century!

The Seven Years' War on a global scale in two volumes. An operational level hex & counter wargame. The first volume, "War of Conquest", covers central Europe. The second volume, "War of Conquest: The Wider World", expands the game to the rest of the world. This is a two player wargame, but if you wish to play in two teams you can, dividing your assets as you see fit. The game can also be played solitaire because, although it uses cards, it is not ‘card driven’ as such.

The base game includes an A1 map of Middle Europe and features unit counters for all those that fight in the main European theatre of war at a regiment or brigade scale. The Wider World expansion adds four more A2 sized maps for Maritime Europe, Latin America, North America, and India, plus extensive named naval units, and numerous colonial units. The Wider World expansion adds naval rules including rules for movement between theatres of war. For the most ambitious players the expansion also includes the Global Grand Campaign that stitches together all theatres of war providing the ultimate bird’s eye view of a world at war.

Taken from back of the box:

Dino-Deck contains 72 cards with 12 colorful dinosaur characters each with 5 symbols about their size, what they ate, and how they walked. Friendly Rex, Claus, Study, Puny, Thor, Lance, Billy, Spike, Packy, Heat Wave, Rolo, and Sarah invite you to play their 5 action-packed card games and learn about dinosaurs.

5 Action-Packed Games:

Meateaters: An exciting game of matching symbols and collecting meat eating dinosaurs!

Dino-Match: Ask your friend for a dinosaur and see if it matches one of yours. If it does -- ask again. When you are out of cards, you win!

Dino-Play: A new fast-paced game of matching card colors and dinosaurs. You get a chance to play 2 cards in 1 turn!

Collect-A-Saurus: A real strategy game. Which card do you choose from your friends' pattern to finish your pattern? Score 100 points and win!

Recall-A-Saurus: How's your memory? This game tests your memory of where the dinosaurs are in a 25 card pattern!"

For the last few months, the citizens of London have been outraged, appalled, and terrified by the killings of the notorious Jack the Ripper.  Stalking the foggy streets of the Whitechapel for fresh victims, the cloaked figure has already killed 5 women and he seems to be ready to murder again.  It is up to you to put an end to his reign of terror. Two missions await in this box.  The first is a family-friendly mystery in the elegant home of one of the ripper suspects.  It is up to you to confirm his identity, uncover hidden passages, and discover his role in this classic escape adventure.  The second, however, is a PG-13 adventure that will put you in the dark alleys of London… one step behind the ripper… where you will examine his latest victims and find yourself hot on his trail.  Let’s hope that he doesn’t turn his attention on you.  It is our scariest mission yet.  Can you escape the ripper?

Subsistence is a compact resource management game that imagines the world behind the standing stones of Neolithic Britain.

Over nine turns, players select idol cards to gain benefits from. These benefits will be additional cards to add to their tableau, or development tokens to place on their land cards- which may trigger additional benefits. After these nine turns, the game ends. Points are scored based on their idols' unique criteria and the placement of their developments. The player with the highest score wins.

Subsistence plays quickly but offers a growing depth of strategic decision-making. It will appeal to players who enjoy careful planning and progression rather than direct conflict.

Time for the Greatest Heist on Earth!  You have a strange mission this time.  An extinct animal, known as the Tasmanian Tiger, has been found back in a depression-era circus.  It will soon disappear into history, so this is your chance to travel back and steal the creature, thus saving the species.  To do so, you will need to pull off a heist of EPIC proportions!  Sneak through the circus train, explore the sideshows, avoid the meddling clowns, and try to find a way to plot out the perfect heist.  You see… the only way to get the tiger will be to steal it from right under the Ringmaster’s nose and in front of a whole tent of paying customers.  Are you able to save the tiger in time… or will you just turn into its next lunch?
